name: 丁秀儀
objective: This course explores the foundational principles of business ethics and their practical applications in modern organizations. Through case studies, ethical frameworks, and global perspectives, students will examine how businesses navigate moral dilemmas, fulfill social responsibilities, and pursue sustainable strategies. The course begins with essential ethical theories and decision-making tools, followed by discussions on responsible management, corporate social responsibility (CSR), and stakeholder engagement. It also addresses the complexities of cultural relativism, professional ethics, and organizational misconduct. In the second half of the semester, students will explore emerging topics such as AI ethics, algorithmic bias, and governance challenges in the digital era. Interactive learning formats—such as group debates, scenario analysis, and student presentations—will help develop critical thinking and ethical awareness. By the end of the course, students will be able to analyze ethical issues from multiple perspectives and propose responsible, context-sensitive solutions in real-world business settings.
schedule:
Week 1	Course Introduction and the Meaning of Business Ethics
Week 2	Moral Reasoning and Ethical Theories
Week 3	Common Ethical Dilemmas in Business
Week 4	Ethical Decision-Making Frameworks and Tools
Week 5	Responsible Management: Three Dimensions
Week 6	Corporate Sustainability and Its Relationship to Business
Week 7	Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) and Stakeholder Theory
Week 8	Cross-Cultural Ethics and Moral Relativism
Week 9	Why Do Good People Do Bad Things?
Week 10	Ethical Challenges in Organizational Practice
Week 11	Sustainability Strategies and Innovation
Week 12	Professional Ethics and Workplace Roles
Week 13	Responsible AI and Algorithmic Bias
Week 14	AI Ethics Governance and Explainability
Week 15	Philosophical Perspectives on AI Ethics
Week 16	Should AI Be Regulated?
Week 17	Integration and Cross-Topic Discussion
Week 18	Final Presentations
